summary: Runs the structural variation discovery workflow on a single sample

arguments.summary: Adapter sequence.
arguments.name: --adapter-sequence

arguments.summary: If true, adds a command line header line to created VCF files.
arguments.name: --add-output-vcf-command-line

arguments.summary: bwa-mem index image file
arguments.name: --aligner-index-image

arguments.summary: Proper pairs have the positive strand read upstream of the negative strand read, but we allow this much slop for short fragments.
arguments.name: --allowed-short-fragment-overhang

arguments.summary: read one or more arguments files and add them to the command line
arguments.name: --arguments_file

arguments.summary: sorting order to be used for the output assembly alignments SAM/BAM file (currently only coordinate or query name is supported)
arguments.name: --assembled-contigs-output-order

arguments.summary: Uncertainty in overlap of assembled breakpoints and evidence target links.
arguments.name: --assembly-imprecise-evidence-overlap-uncertainty

arguments.summary: Guess at the ratio of reads in the final assembly to the number reads mapped to the interval.
arguments.name: --assembly-to-mapped-size-ratio-guess

arguments.summary: maximum number of bytes to read from a file into each partition of reads. Setting this higher will result in fewer partitions. Note that this will not be equal to the size of the partition in memory. Defaults to 0, which uses the default split size (determined by the Hadoop input format, typically the size of one HDFS block).
arguments.name: --bam-partition-size

arguments.summary: directory for evidence output
arguments.name: --breakpoint-evidence-dir

arguments.summary: file for breakpoint intervals output
arguments.name: --breakpoint-intervals

arguments.summary: KmerCleaner maximum copy number (not count, but copy number) for a kmer. Kmers observed too frequently are probably mismapped or ubiquitous.
arguments.name: --cleaner-max-copy-number

arguments.summary: KmerCleaner maximum number of intervals for a localizing kmer. If a kmer occurs in too many intervals, it isn't sufficiently local.
arguments.name: --cleaner-max-intervals

arguments.summary: KmerCleaner minimum kmer count for a localizing kmer.  If we see it less often than this many times, we're guessing it's erroneous.
arguments.name: --cleaner-min-kmer-count

arguments.summary: External CNV calls file. Should be single sample VCF, and contain only confident autosomal non-reference CNV calls (for now).
arguments.name: --cnv-calls

arguments.summary: Spark properties to set on the Spark context in the format <property>=<value>
arguments.name: --conf

arguments.summary: sam file for aligned contigs
arguments.name: --contig-sam-file

arguments.summary: If true, create a BAM index when writing a coordinate-sorted BAM file.
arguments.name: --create-output-bam-index

arguments.summary: If true, create a BAM splitting index (SBI) when writing a coordinate-sorted BAM file.
arguments.name: --create-output-bam-splitting-index

arguments.summary: If true, create a VCF index when writing a coordinate-sorted VCF file.
arguments.name: --create-output-variant-index

arguments.summary: file containing alt contig names that will be ignored when looking for inter-contig pairs
arguments.name: --cross-contigs-to-ignore
arguments.fulltext: This is a path to a text file of contig names (one per line) that will be ignored when looking for inter-contig pairs.

arguments.summary: Run interpretation tool in debug mode (more information print to screen)
arguments.name: --debug-mode

arguments.summary: Read filters to be disabled before analysis
arguments.name: --disable-read-filter

arguments.summary: If specified, do not check the sequence dictionaries from our inputs for compatibility. Use at your own risk!
arguments.name: --disable-sequence-dictionary-validation

arguments.summary: Disable all tool default read filters (WARNING: many tools will not function correctly without their default read filters on)
arguments.name: --disable-tool-default-read-filters

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals to exclude from processing
arguments.name: --exclude-intervals
arguments.fulltext:
Use this argument to exclude certain parts of the genome from the analysis (like -L, but the opposite).
 This argument can be specified multiple times. You can use samtools-style intervals either explicitly on the
 command line (e.g. -XL 1 or -XL 1:100-200) or by loading in a file containing a list of intervals
 (e.g. -XL myFile.intervals).

arguments.summary: Exclusion interval padding.
arguments.name: --exclusion-interval-padding

arguments.summary: file of reference intervals to exclude
arguments.name: --exclusion-intervals
arguments.fulltext:
This is a file that calls out the coordinates of intervals in the reference assembly to exclude from
 consideration when calling putative breakpoints.
 Each line is a tab-delimited interval with 1-based inclusive coordinates like this:
  chr1	124535434	142535434

arguments.summary: flag to signal that user wants to run experimental interpretation tool as well
arguments.name: --exp-interpret

arguments.summary: Traverse assembly graph and produce contigs for all paths.
arguments.name: --expand-assembly-graph

arguments.summary: external evidence input file
arguments.name: --external-evidence

arguments.summary: Uncertainty in location of external evidence.
arguments.name: --external-evidence-uncertainty

arguments.summary: Weight to give external evidence.
arguments.name: --external-evidence-weight

arguments.summary: output dir for assembled fastqs
arguments.name: --fastq-dir

arguments.summary: A configuration file to use with the GATK.
arguments.name: --gatk-config-file

arguments.summary: If the GCS bucket channel errors out, how many times it will attempt to re-initiate the connection
arguments.name: --gcs-max-retries

arguments.summary: Project to bill when accessing "requester pays" buckets. If unset, these buckets cannot be accessed.  User must have storage.buckets.get permission on the bucket being accessed.
arguments.name: --gcs-project-for-requester-pays

arguments.summary: display the help message
arguments.name: --help

arguments.summary: file for high-coverage intervals output
arguments.name: --high-coverage-intervals

arguments.summary: We filter out contiguous regions of the genome that have coverage of at least high-depth-coverage-factor * avg-coverage and a peak coverage of high-depth-coverage-peak-factor * avg-coverage, because the reads mapped to those regions tend to be non-local and high depth prevents accurate assembly.
arguments.name: --high-depth-coverage-factor

arguments.summary: We filter out contiguous regions of the genome that have coverage of at least high-depth-coverage-factor * avg-coverage and a peak coverage of high-depth-coverage-peak-factor * avg-coverage, because the reads mapped to those regions tend to be non-local and high depth prevents accurate assembly.
arguments.name: --high-depth-coverage-peak-factor

arguments.summary: Number of pieces of imprecise evidence necessary to call a variant in the absence of an assembled breakpoint.
arguments.name: --imprecise-variant-evidence-threshold

arguments.summary: Include read mapping location in FASTQ files.
arguments.name: --include-mapping-location

arguments.summary: BAM/SAM/CRAM file containing reads
arguments.name: --input

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are excluding.
arguments.name: --interval-exclusion-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -XL. For example, '-XL 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-XL 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Interval merging rule for abutting intervals
arguments.name: --interval-merging-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program merges abutting intervals (i.e. intervals that are directly side-by-side but do not
 actually overlap) into a single continuous interval. However you can change this behavior if you want them to be
 treated as separate intervals instead.

arguments.summary: Don't look for extra reads mapped outside the interval.
arguments.name: --interval-only-assembly

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are including.
arguments.name: --interval-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -L. For example, '-L 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-L 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Set merging approach to use for combining interval inputs
arguments.name: --interval-set-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program will take the UNION of all intervals specified using -L and/or -XL. However, you can
 change this setting for -L, for example if you want to take the INTERSECTION of the sets instead. E.g. to
 perform the analysis only on chromosome 1 exomes, you could specify -L exomes.intervals -L 1 --interval-set-rule
 INTERSECTION. However, it is not possible to modify the merging approach for intervals passed using -XL (they will
 always be merged using UNION).

 Note that if you specify both -L and -XL, the -XL interval set will be subtracted from the -L interval set.

options.summary: Take the union of all intervals
options.name: UNION

options.summary: Take the intersection of intervals (the subset that overlaps all intervals specified)
options.name: INTERSECTION

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals over which to operate
arguments.name: --intervals

arguments.summary: Kmer size.
arguments.name: --k-size

arguments.summary: file for kmer intervals output
arguments.name: --kmer-intervals

arguments.summary: Maximum kmer DUST score.
arguments.name: --kmer-max-dust-score

arguments.summary: file containing ubiquitous kmer list. see FindBadGenomicKmersSpark to generate it.
arguments.name: --kmers-to-ignore
arguments.fulltext:
This is a path to a file of kmers that appear too frequently in the reference to be usable as probes to localize
 reads.  We don't calculate it here, because it depends only on the reference.
 The program FindBadGenomicKmersSpark can produce such a list for you.

arguments.summary: Maximum size deletion to call based on imprecise evidence without corroborating read depth evidence
arguments.name: --max-callable-imprecise-deletion-size

arguments.summary: Maximum total bases in FASTQs that can be assembled.
arguments.name: --max-fastq-size

arguments.summary: Largest fragment size that will be explicitly counted in determining fragment size statistics.
arguments.name: --max-tracked-fragment-length

arguments.summary: Minimum flanking alignment length
arguments.name: --min-align-length

arguments.summary: Minimum weight of the evidence that shares a distal target locus to validate the evidence, as a ratio of the mean coverage in the BAM. The default value is coherent-count / mean coverage ~ 7 / 42.9 ~ 0.163
arguments.name: --min-coherent-evidence-coverage-ratio

arguments.summary: Minimum weight of the corroborating read evidence to validate some single piece of evidence, as a ratio of the mean coverage in the BAM. The default value is overlap-count / mean coverage ~ 15 / 42.9 ~ 0.350
arguments.name: --min-evidence-coverage-ratio

arguments.summary: The minimum mapping quality for reads used to gather evidence of breakpoints.
arguments.name: --min-evidence-mapq

arguments.summary: The minimum length of the matched portion of an interesting alignment.  Reads that don't match at least this many reference bases won't be used in gathering evidence.
arguments.name: --min-evidence-match-length

arguments.summary: Minimum number of localizing kmers in a valid interval.
arguments.name: --min-kmers-per-interval

arguments.summary: Minimum mapping quality of evidence assembly contig
arguments.name: --min-mq

arguments.summary: For tools that shuffle data or write an output, sets the number of reducers. Defaults to 0, which gives one partition per 10MB of input.
arguments.name: --num-reducers

arguments.summary: directory for VCF output, including those from experimental interpretation tool if so requested, will be created if not present; sample name will be appended after the provided argument
arguments.name: --output

arguments.summary: when writing a bam, in single sharded mode this directory to write the temporary intermediate output shards, if not specified .parts/ will be used
arguments.name: --output-shard-tmp-dir

arguments.summary: Aggressively simplify local assemblies, ignoring small variants.
arguments.name: --pop-variant-bubbles

arguments.summary: Name of the program running
arguments.name: --program-name

arguments.summary: file for mapped qname intervals output
arguments.name: --qname-intervals-for-assembly

arguments.summary: file for mapped qname intervals output
arguments.name: --qname-intervals-mapped

arguments.summary: Whether to suppress job-summary info on System.err.
arguments.name: --QUIET

arguments.summary: Read filters to be applied before analysis
arguments.name: --read-filter

arguments.summary: Indices to use for the read inputs. If specified, an index must be provided for every read input and in the same order as the read inputs. If this argument is not specified, the path to the index for each input will be inferred automatically.
arguments.name: --read-index

arguments.summary: output file for read metadata
arguments.name: --read-metadata

arguments.summary: Validation stringency for all SAM/BAM/CRAM/SRA files read by this program.  The default stringency value SILENT can improve performance when processing a BAM file in which variable-length data (read, qualities, tags) do not otherwise need to be decoded.
arguments.name: --read-validation-stringency

arguments.summary: Reference sequence file
arguments.name: --reference

arguments.summary: Simplify local assemblies by removing contigs shadowed by similar contigs.
arguments.name: --remove-shadowed-contigs

arguments.summary: Allow evidence filter to run without gaps annotation (assume no gaps).
arguments.name: --run-without-gaps-annotation

arguments.summary: Allow evidence filter to run without annotation for single-read mappability of 100-mers (assume all mappable).
arguments.name: --run-without-umap-s100-annotation

arguments.summary: For tools that write an output, write the output in multiple pieces (shards)
arguments.name: --sharded-output

arguments.summary: display hidden arguments
arguments.name: --showHidden

arguments.summary: URL of the Spark Master to submit jobs to when using the Spark pipeline runner.
arguments.name: --spark-master

arguments.summary: Spark verbosity. Overrides --verbosity for Spark-generated logs only. Possible values: {ALL, DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR, FATAL, OFF, TRACE}
arguments.name: --spark-verbosity

arguments.summary: Granularity to use when writing a splitting index, one entry will be put into the index every n reads where n is this granularity value. Smaller granularity results in a larger index with more available split points.
arguments.name: --splitting-index-granularity

arguments.summary: Path to xgboost classifier model file for evidence filtering
arguments.name: --sv-evidence-filter-model-file

arguments.summary: Minimum classified probability for a piece of evidence to pass xgboost evidence filter
arguments.name: --sv-evidence-filter-threshold-probability

arguments.summary: Filter method for selecting evidence to group into Assembly Intervals
arguments.name: --sv-evidence-filter-type

arguments.summary: Path to file enumerating gaps in the reference genome, used by classifier to score evidence for filtering. To use classifier without specifying gaps file, pass the flag --run-without-gaps-annotation
arguments.name: --sv-genome-gaps-file

arguments.summary: Path to single read 100-mer mappability file in the reference genome, used by classifier to score evidence for filtering. To use classifier without specifying mappability file, pass the flag --run-without-umap-s100-annotation
arguments.name: --sv-genome-umap-s100-file

arguments.summary: output file for non-assembled breakpoints in bedpe format
arguments.name: --target-link-file

arguments.summary: Temp directory to use.
arguments.name: --tmp-dir

arguments.summary: Breakpoint padding for evaluation against truth data.
arguments.name: --truth-interval-padding

arguments.summary: directory for evidence output
arguments.name: --unfiltered-breakpoint-evidence-dir

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkDeflater (as opposed to IntelDeflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-deflater

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkInflater (as opposed to IntelInflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-inflater

arguments.summary: Whether to use NIO or the Hadoop filesystem (default) for reading files. (Note that the Hadoop filesystem is always used for writing files.)
arguments.name: --use-nio

arguments.summary: Control verbosity of logging.
arguments.name: --verbosity

arguments.summary: display the version number for this tool
arguments.name: --version

arguments.summary: Write GFA representation of assemblies in fastq-dir.
arguments.name: --write-gfas

arguments.summary: ZDropoff (see Bwa mem manual) for contig alignment.
arguments.name: --z-dropoff

description:
Runs the structural variation discovery workflow on a single sample

This tool packages the algorithms described in FindBreakpointEvidenceSpark and org.broadinstitute.hellbender.tools.spark.sv.discovery.DiscoverVariantsFromContigAlignmentsSAMSpark as an integrated workflow. Please consult the descriptions of those tools for more details about the algorithms employed. In brief, input reads are examined for evidence of structural variation in a genomic region, regions so identified are locally assembled, and the local assemblies are called for structural variation.

Inputs

  • An input file of aligned reads.
  • The reference to which the reads have been aligned.
  • A BWA index image for the reference. You can use BwaMemIndexImageCreator to create the index image file.
  • A list of ubiquitous kmers to ignore. You can use FindBadGenomicGenomicKmersSpark to create the list of kmers to ignore.

Output

  • A sam file with all of the contigs generated by local assemblies aligned to reference.
  • A vcf file describing the discovered structural variants.

Optional Output

Extra, optional output is generated when the experimental interpretation unit is run (note that they may change as features are still being experimented and added)
  • several VCF files containing variants discovered via different code path (ultimately will be merged into a single VCF)
  • query name sorted SAM file of local assembly contigs from whose alignments we can not yet make un-ambiguous calls (intended for debugging and future developments)

Usage example

   gatk StructuralVariationDiscoveryPipelineSpark \
     -I input_reads.bam \
     -R reference.2bit \
     --aligner-index-image reference.img \
     --kmers-to-ignore kmers_to_ignore.txt \
     --contig-sam-file aligned_contigs.sam \
     -O structural_variants.vcf

This tool can be run without explicitly specifying Spark options. That is to say, the given example command without Spark options will run locally. See Tutorial#10060 for an example of how to set up and run a Spark tool on a cloud Spark cluster.

Caveats

Expected input is a paired-end, coordinate-sorted BAM with around 30x coverage. Coverage much lower than that probably won't work well.

The reference is broadcast by Spark, and must therefore be a .2bit file due to current restrictions.
name: StructuralVariationDiscoveryPipelineSpark
